segment.source: Relative to Windows 8/8.1, the recommended implementation in Windows 10 for such hardware buttons has been greatly simplified.
segment.target: Relative to Windows 8/8.1, the recommended implementation in Windows 10 for such hardware buttons has been greatly simplified.

segment.source: You no longer need to copy Windows boot files to an unmanaged location on the EFI system partition (ESP) to create a secondary boot path.
segment.target: You no longer need to copy Windows boot files to an unmanaged location on the EFI system partition (ESP) to create a secondary boot path.

segment.source: Instead, Windows configures and manages all the on-disk resources required to support the hardware buttons.
segment.target: Instead, Windows configures and manages all the on-disk resources required to support the hardware buttons.

segment.source: Windows 10 automatically creates a secondary Boot Configuration Data (BCD) store in the folder EFIMicrosoftRecovery.
segment.target: Windows 10 automatically creates a secondary Boot Configuration Data (BCD) store in the folder EFIMicrosoftRecovery.

segment.source: When Windows RE is installed, this secondary BCD store is automatically populated with the appropriate settings to boot Windows RE by default.
segment.target: When Windows RE is installed, this secondary BCD store is automatically populated with the appropriate settings to boot Windows RE by default.

segment.source: If the location of Windows RE changes (for example, due to future updates), the secondary BCD store is updated automatically.
segment.target: If the location of Windows RE changes (for example, due to future updates), the secondary BCD store is updated automatically.

segment.source: You will still need to create a static boot device entry for recovery at the end of the UEFI firmware boot order list.
segment.target: You will still need to create a static boot device entry for recovery at the end of the UEFI firmware boot order list.

segment.source: This boot device entry should point to the default Windows Boot Manager (bootmgfw.efi) in the folder EFIMicrosoftBoot on the ESP.
segment.target: This boot device entry should point to the default Windows Boot Manager (bootmgfw.efi) in the folder EFIMicrosoftBoot on the ESP.

segment.source: The boot device entry must specify the parameter.
segment.target: The boot device entry must specify the parameter.

segment.source: When the hardware button is triggered, the recovery boot device entry should be selected automatically.
segment.target: When the hardware button is triggered, the recovery boot device entry should be selected automatically.

segment.source: To learn more, see your hardware manufacturer's instructions for modifying the UEFI firmware on the device.
segment.target: To learn more, see your hardware manufacturer's instructions for modifying the UEFI firmware on the device.

segment.source: When Windows Boot Manager is launched with the parameter, it uses the secondary BCD store which is configured to boot Windows RE, instead of the default BCD store.
segment.target: When Windows Boot Manager is launched with the parameter, it uses the secondary BCD store which is configured to boot Windows RE, instead of the default BCD store.

segment.source: Design recommendations for the hardware button:
segment.target: Design recommendations for the hardware button:

segment.source: The hardware recovery button (or button combination) should be usable even when the PC is powered off.
segment.target: The hardware recovery button (or button combination) should be usable even when the PC is powered off.

segment.source: When triggered, the PC should power on and go through the secondary boot path.
segment.target: When triggered, the PC should power on and go through the secondary boot path.

segment.source: This eliminates the need for users to press the button within a very short time window during and after POST.
segment.target: This eliminates the need for users to press the button within a very short time window during and after POST.

segment.source: For PCs which support firmware options menu, triggering the button (or button combination) should first display a simple menu which gives users the options to either boot Windows RE or to enter the firmware options menu.
segment.target: For PCs which support firmware options menu, triggering the button (or button combination) should first display a simple menu which gives users the options to either boot Windows RE or to enter the firmware options menu.

segment.source: This removes the need to support multiple button combinations.
segment.target: This removes the need to support multiple button combinations.

segment.source: Note The hardware button will not be able to boot the PC into Windows RE until Windows RE is installed.
segment.target: Note The hardware button will not be able to boot the PC into Windows RE until Windows RE is installed.

segment.source: In general, this means after the PC has completed the Specialize configuration pass.
